analyzed: theḥ apadāna  nāga sa māla vagga
translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter with Nāgasamāla

analyzed: ṭhita añjali yat theḥ a padāna
translated: The Elder Ṭhitañjali’s Birth Story
“In the past I was a hunter
in a forest grove in the wilderness;
there I saw the Buddha,
with thirty-two excellent marks.
There I put my hands together in salutation
and left, facing east,
sitting not far away,

analyzed: niyake paṇṇa santhare  tatas me asanīpātaḥ
translated: on a leaf-hut roof.🔽Then a lightning bolt
struck my head right then;
at the time of my death,
I put my hands together in salutation again.
Twenty-two eons ago,
I put my hands together in salutation then;
I do not recall any bad destination,
this is the fruit of putting my hands together in salutation.
In the Catupaññāsa eon,
named Migaketuka,
endowed with the seven treasures,
a powerful wheel-turning monarch.
The four analytical insights …
… the Buddha’s instruction has been done.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā ṭhitañjaliyo thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā ṭhitañjaliyaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: Thus the elder Ṭhitañjali recited these verses.
The Elder Ṭhitañjali’s Birth Story, the ninth.
